emerging_technologies.name: General Purpose Autonomous Agents (GPAA)
emerging_technologies.description: Agents capable of handling a wide range of tasks beyond their initial programming, adapting to new environments and learning from experience.
emerging_technologies.societal_implications: Potential for significant job displacement, increased automation efficiency, and personalized services; requires new regulations on AI ethics and employment laws.
emerging_technologies.adoption_factors: Industry demand for versatile automation, technological breakthroughs in AI, regulatory acceptance, and public trust in autonomous systems.

emerging_technologies.name: Emotionally Intelligent AI Agents (EIA)
emerging_technologies.description: AI agents that can recognize, interpret, and respond to human emotions, enhancing interaction quality.
emerging_technologies.societal_implications: Improves emotional support systems but raises concerns about privacy, manipulation, and the authenticity of emotional responses.
emerging_technologies.adoption_factors: Demand for empathetic AI, advancements in affective computing, and integration into daily life tools.

emerging_technologies.name: Decentralized Autonomous Organizations (DAOs) for AI Governance
emerging_technologies.description: AI-driven organizations that operate autonomously through blockchain-based governance structures.
emerging_technologies.societal_implications: Could lead to new forms of corporate structure, reducing human bias in decision-making but requiring new legal frameworks for accountability.
emerging_technologies.adoption_factors: Growing interest in decentralized systems, blockchain technology maturity, and regulatory acceptance of AI in governance.

mainstream_technologies.name: Task-Specific Autonomous Agents (TSAA)
mainstream_technologies.description: AI agents designed for specific tasks, now widely adopted in industries like logistics, manufacturing, and retail.
mainstream_technologies.adoption_status: Standardized processes, widespread industry adoption, and public acceptance of AI in specific roles.

mainstream_technologies.name: AI-Driven Supply Chain Management
mainstream_technologies.description: AI systems optimizing supply chain operations from procurement to delivery, ensuring efficiency and resilience.
mainstream_technologies.adoption_status: Becoming a standard in global supply chains, with companies investing heavily in AI to gain competitive advantages.

epoch_themes.description: The creation of ecosystems where multiple autonomous agents work together to achieve complex objectives.
epoch_themes.societal_impact: Transforms how work is done, potentially reducing human oversight in many sectors but also introducing new forms of digital labor.
epoch_themes.global_trends: Increased focus on AI ethics, regulation for AI governance, and integration of AI into daily life.

epoch_themes.theme: Emotional and Social Intelligence in AI
epoch_themes.description: Enhancement of AI to better understand and engage with human emotional and social cues.
epoch_themes.societal_impact: Improves human-AI interaction, potentially reducing social isolation but also raising ethical concerns about manipulation and privacy.
epoch_themes.global_trends: Growing demand for personalized services, increased research in affective computing, and societal push for AI that respects human values.
